Aye yo it's going down this Saturday, May 3rd from 12 to 7 at Down South Texas BBQ, 1716 W. Howard Lane in North Austin for the Cinco de Mayo Smoked Taco Extravaganza. Hosted by me, Pitmaestro Rico, and sponsored by Standing Ovations and 88.7 KAZI. We'll have vendors, music by DJ five-O, and good vibes all day long. Plus, our Saturday specials like smoked oxtails, mmm. We're serving brisket, carnitas, jerk goat, barbacoa, birria, and carne guisada tacos -hey. Guest chefs include Pablo, Walter of Reflectionz BBQ, Chef Drew, and Chef Brúz throwing down on crawfish. Follow us @DSTXBBQ on IG or Facebook for all the details. Born in the smoke, raised in the flavor.

The Morning Grind on 88.7 fm kazi is produced with support from Park's Coffee. Park's Coffee is fresh roasted each day right here in Texas. Discover Texas roasted premium choice and gourmet brands at parkscoffee.com.

30 days can make a difference. This is Focus on Women. I'm Celeste. All week we've been talking about the 30-Day Power Focus, a system designed to yield results in 30 days. Perhaps you are sick and tired of being sick and tired and you need and want a breakthrough. This 30-Day Power Focus can help. If you have been previously letting your fears reign, choose today to take control of your mind and only let thoughts that support your desired outcome enter. What will help you get where you want to go? Capture your limiting thoughts and consciously choose to replace them with your vision, hope, and your dream until they become your dominant thoughts. Additionally, it is vital that you make some basic plans. There's an old saying, if you fail to plan, you plan to fail. Haven't you heard that before? Well, it certainly is true because if you don't have a plan for your day in your life, I guarantee you someone else around you will have a plan for you. Now keep in mind that just because you plan, it doesn't mean it will come out exactly as thought. As a matter of fact, if you're wise, you'll leave the option open for God
to help you achieve what you have planned or better. Better is always good. Remember what Ryan Tracy said yesterday. Be clear of where you want to go. Plan for it, but remain flexible on how you get there. For Focus on Women, I'm Celeste Johnson.
We're here to educate and empower. The Morning Grind.

I must have just been in some very specific part of the city
No, but it is -  you know what, I would say it is one of the - still one of the most segregated cities.
Ohh, heard. Yeah i did notice, i did notice that, yeah. The difference between the inner city versus…

I gotta say though,  for, in the spring there is... Chicago is like,  great.  That  was the last time we were there together we went in the spring and it was like, "oh yeah," i was like, "oh man this is not like when i came last time it was snow i was like nah this is not-" again the spring I was like, "okay if Chicago could stay like this year round it would be the biggest city in the country."
Mmmhm, yep
[Audio cuts out] Yep, that makes all that makes all the sense in the world.
Yeah, i'm like, "i'm not coming out for no christmas y'all gotta be crazy. Whatever. See ya."
You might not make it out, in that weather. Lord.

You know. But yeah, the spring - the spring and the fall? Beautiful. Because in fall you really get to see - like by the time you see the trees change colors here, we're like, in December already. But by fall, oh, you see all the pretty colors...
I love that.

So yeah, you know it's like - i love, i love going to visit and going to do different things, there's always so much to do. You know it's just it's gonna always be something that reminds me of why I moved away.
Right! [Laughs] Valid.
uh-oh! Time to get that there on a flight, let's get on up [laughs]
It'll roll up on you quick, you'll be like "oh okay, yeah, we stay... oh okay"

[Audio cuts out] -didn't really know, um and just you know bring them in, like you said - bring them into a different light that helps me have more respect. Like, that's how I felt when I watched, I mean this is a biography, but the Luther Vandross biography. I know i keep bringing that up, but like--
Oh my god. It was wonderful!
It was really… phenomenal.
It hit me really hard.
It really hit.
Yeah, when they - they featured that here.
Oh wow, really. Oh my-
uh-huh, yeah, yeah -- the pan-African, the pan-African film festival, when they did that, um, they did that here.
Okay.
We went to the premiere.
But there's a couple different Luther [Vandross] uh… documentaries, though, right?
Yeah no, there's several, there's definitely several out, but the most recent one--
You have him. Yes, they just recently put it up on uh the streaming channel
okay yeah did y'all see the Sly and the Family Stone...?
No, i didn't see that

What i did see though, was um, it came out a few years back, and i think Questlove helped put it together. It's when they did this big [Harlem Festival] -- it was, it was like, it was like, I mean Nina Simone, you know it was awesome. I'm sitting up there like, because i have an elder - I had a elder family member with me at that time-- tears rolling, because they were like, "I remember that. You could[n't?] get to it from Chicago." But it was - on that day, so much was going on in the world, and we were doing that.
Oh my goodness, I love that documentary--

And no violence. No violence, there was no violence over the two weeks. And, I don't know if you heard the story behind this, but Questlove found all those tapes in a garage sale! It was in the back of somebody's garage!
That makes me want to go to everybody garage sale, you know?
I was like, "wow"

because you know, you never know. It's just like when i'm here in Austin and i'm down there working at the Victory Grill, right, and to hear, you know, Mr. Holmes daughter talk about how when she was going to, um, school at Prairie View [A&M University], and she would come home and they would - they would work, and then you know oh yeah you got somebody like a BB King or a Body Blue Band and to them, at that time, they're just people performing. You know what i'm saying, and you don't recognize these getting ready to come to be legends, you know and you can imagine that, even then, that somebody - you know, these were just some artists: "oh let's get this artist, let's get that" -- they weren't in their prime-prime time, they were doing their thing, you know what i'm saying? And somebody just had that, you know, and it's like... now it's, you know ~museum~ [laughs] worthy now, to have that.

He said that the... uh quality, you know that they shot it in, they thought that they were going to be able to sell that later on, but nobody ever picked it up so it ended up in the back of someone's garage.
Crazy
...because they couldn't sell it.
Yeah. Also they purposely hid it because they didn't want to air the fact that like, black people in large amounts of groups could hang out and be chill and have fun and create and organize--
and there were other groups… there were latinos there, yes.
and it was packed

and they didn't want people to know that, and they -- I loved how all of it was basically uh just a huge community effort, um I can't recall the name of the guy -- [Mz. Marlah: Harlem Culture Festival] yeah… the man?
And it was supported by the then-mayor… of New York City.
right right oh my goodness who was white!

who was white but was like, down. [DJ Bean: right he was down] and so you [Mz. Marlah: Summer of Soul]. So if you haven't seen that, I think that's definitely worth your time - would you guys agree that's worth your time to watch?
oh  yes i want to buy it. I'm like how do i own it? I need a physical copy.
Did they win academy award for best documentary?
I believe they did. I think he literally won.
yes yeah so yeah that's i mean it's definitely worth your time folks if you haven't seen it, it's on Hulu right now .
It's just awesome - it's awesome black music history - period.

It is, and it starts out with stevie wonder and he just whacking the drums like with like with a power and a force that just moves you i love it it's like throughout the whole thing you feel like you're in the audience, watching the film and i'm it makes me tear up because i wish i was there. I want to be exactly right put me in you know me like somebody needs to create a time machine so i can just attend that moment like...
you know, I think you see gil scott harron that's when, the revolution will not be televised -
and they literally didn't televise it

that festival yes I mean man, right now you could - I don't even think they could afford to do that right now, with the equivalent talent, I mean because that ticket would probably cost like a thousand dollars a head
ah true, unless it was like, sponsored by somebody

we call it the ESSENCE Festival of Culture now [laughs] because in new orleans honey, every year we bring all of those people together, I remember the very first ESSENCE Festival of Culture, wait in new orleans - i can't say it right -  new orleans or the nola, down in the nola.
yeah we heard you last week - don't call, we- we got you.
you know, if you want to call in you know that's cool

we haven't really opened it up yet go ahead but yeah it was like it was it was their very first one so of course you're gonna have artists coming in like anita baker didn't come on till like an hour later but her plane so you know you had all these artists so i'm like looking at you know it's you it's luther vandruff's it's earth wind and fire it's anita baker it's um who were the young cats then? Uh boys to men a whole little village of black vendors so you can get everything everything you need clothes and jewelry and a purse and so then then they had these little uh they call them like the little uh little club little lounges so in the lounge you could see like old group like cameo you know what i'm saying to be somebody like that performing it's like  wait wait wait wait wait, you know, so-
They have cameo in the lounge? Wow.

It was so much, because you could sit there privately - not privately, but intimate.  So it was like whoever was in in there at then at that time was there. Everybody was there. It was like some legends that aren't even here with us anymore so to get to see that to see them go through that first one it was you know for me it was amazing it was fun it was like three days of -  and then when you go when you were outside because it was conference [audio breaks] accident and Al Sharpton and everyone doing they thing. But then the businesses outside were like this, "Welcome! Welcome ESSENCE music festival come on and shop with us!" Oh my god, they worked us. They worked us and it was it was hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of buses from all over the united states full of us skin folks and we had so much fun and that's so there wasn't any violence there wasn't any - you know what I'm saying?
Of course not!

because i hate it when we when when they say "when we get together there's always -" oh my god, honey, I partied with a woman who called me "guhl" all night: "guhl, ain't this fun" "guhl, here we go party guhl" and it took me um all night to realize she was saying "girl." You know like like "go on girl!"
[laughing] yeah yeah yeah you were like "suuure."
"am I a guhl? What?"
"what is a guhl?" You were rocking with it like "i guess..."
Yeah, different - you know, different festivals and stuff, I love it.
I wish they did something like that in Austin, I would love to have a black - all-black music festival in Austin.

Well we can do that, it's enough promoters out here… give Miss Marlah a call, let's hook that up, call the station. because you know [audio cuts out] going on but, we do, but it takes us all of us to promote because you know you got to get that moolah-
Right, true - the moolah, and then the outreach -
Exactly, so i feel like we get somebody from outside -
If you get the sponsors - if you get the sponsors, you can get the talent.
Right! Exactly because the talent just needs the money, sponsors got the money, but sponsors want the people - boom everything works out, you feel me? Synergy. Just links up.
But you gotta get the sponsors nailed down which is I mean quite honestly, you got, I mean that's why the ESSENCE fest works because  - the brand, the ESSENCE brand is like hey pull up
Because even um - what's her name? - Was there, the beautiful woman - I can't think of - we just lost her
Oh yeah, you got, yeah, uh, see oh it's the editor-in-chief
Yeah because she always had her hair "look i'm all physical," yes, and cornrows, and i think we just might have lost her
Yeah i think so yeah she's editor-in-chief
you know ESSENCE magazine it's been an awesome magazine
oh yeah iconic. Iconic. Right right up there with Ebony

yes exactly. Coming out of - it used to come out the same building. My team worked for [Johnson Publishing Company] so when you driving down that [inaudible], you know that you can look over and see the building.

I used to be the vice president over at Ebony magazine, so it's it's it's it's a little it's a little disappointing that we could not get it together enough to to get our own festival. But I - I hear that the new folks are trying to do that they got they should they got their own fast channel and so yeah ebony has been through a lot of changes but uh oh yeah it is uh it is they they are trying to get their act together i hear
well because i mean you have new it's a whole different new generation
oh yeah Mr. Johnson's, Mr. Johnson is -
I'm like oh my god how old are they? You know - the family, with their family from generation to generation, you know-
Linda's the last- Linda is the last leftover from that family
Or, member of the family?
Yeah Linda, that used to be my direct report uh i used to report to Linda Johnson, but she, uh, is now blind. She lost her sight… two years ago, yeah.

But yeah, all that to say, if you got the brand yeah you can usually get the sponsors right i think you can get the people, so, right. You know, shout out to ESSENCE, they are still doing it they're doing - I think - what year is this for the ESSENCE fest? It's their 20th year, or something?
It's got to be because it was late 90s when I went to the very first one
yeah and i've never been i feel like i need to make that happen
make the trek down there

okay so we gotta have some Texans up in there
right we got - of course, of course always. You know the south is a really big part of like

Lucky Daye, Brent Faiyaz, Fridayy, don't let me go, Giveon, don't let me go -- [yess, oh you know!] don't -  I'm the r&b male queen baby, [yes ma'am!] don't ever tell me r&b is dead, no it's not!

you better know it

okay okay so who do you say?

DEI, right, inclusion, equity and-
she's black-adjacent

she's black-adjacent
i mean we've always had our uh, blue-eyed soul [no you right] our blue-eyed soul sisters and brothers [that's right] i mean i don't think Tina Marie would have ever made it in the white community -

K-A-Z-I, 88.7. Austin.
The views and opinions expressed on The Morning Grind are not necessarily the views or opinions of K-A-Z-I's board, staff, underwriters, or volunteers.
We're here to entertain, educate, and empower. The Morning Grind.
[Singing] We're back, we're back, we're back, we're back. We're back, we're back, we're back, we're back.
Hey y'all, you're tuned in to the Morning Grind

K-A-Z-I, and online, K-A-Z-I, 88.7 FM dot O-R-G. Yeah, we're coming at you today with that traffic and weather, because it's that time. As you can tell, the traffic bet is playing. Whenever you hear this, it means we're going to hit you with that traffic. Anyway, it looks like on I-35 northbound, we have a stalled vehicle, southbound and northbound right now. Both lanes are blocked, so I'm so sorry if you have somewhere to be on I-35, you might not get there on time. Hopefully you're not late, because if you are, you're out of luck, and I'm so sorry. Really, I hope a miracle happens to you today. Polonia Road and Rolling Ridge Road are still flooded. I have no idea what's going on with that situation, I'm not going to lie.
Flooding over there is crazy.

I'm saying, I'm like, they need to fix that, because it's been way too long for something like this to be going on. But, you know, I'm sure somebody will tap in. Hopefully, if not, they'll hear me yapping about it and get too annoyed that they actually do something about it. But we also have two other crashes, one on First Street and another one on Spicewood Springs. It looks like the other two crashes this morning got taken care of, but Spicewood Springs crash is still on the road, and the one on First Street is in recent development. So please stay safe, y'all. Make sure you're taking care of your fellow drivers on the road. Make sure you're seeing, you know, conscious of other drivers on the road. And don't hit nobody, please. It makes me really sad. I will cry on air.
Your insurance rates will go up.
Your insurance will go up. I will cry. [She will cry] The rain will come out.
You ain't lying.
She will cry.
It's going to be a whole thing. But anyway, we'll hit you with the weather now.

Yeah, Austin right now, 72 degrees, partly cloudy. But actually, it's not over at the station, over on Wall Street. We got clear skies. So I don't really know. But at any rate, it's saying it's going to get high today. It's going to be 79 degrees. And it's saying that we can expect some rain this afternoon. But I don't know, y'all.
I don't really trust the weather these days.
It's just like, well, you know, don't put that on me, man.
[Laughs] No, no, no. It's not your fault. You're just reporting it. You're the messenger. But I'm saying I don't trust the sky.

I got you. I got you. But they're saying right now, if you want to go out and run, it's going to be good weather for that. If you want to go out and ride your bike, it's going to be good weather for that. It's saying that if Ms. Marlah wants to go out there and garden, it's going to be good for that. [Audio cuts out] You're up in a protective style because it could go poof at any moment. [Laughs] It's seven miles. Good visibility right now is still going to be sunset at 8:09. But overall, y'all, I say I'm cautiously optimistic that you don't have to bring an umbrella with you. But it wouldn't be a bad idea to have one close by.
Gotcha.
Yeah.
Wow.
And that's the weather.
Well, thank you, Mr. Mikel.
Yes, thank you, Father. [Laughs] Thank you.
Thank you, Father. [Laughing] Are you part of the conclave?
Are you part of the conclaaave?
Yes. Why yes, I am, I am -
And thank you, Baby Llama. Better known as DJ Bean.
Blake Rowan.
Because she is the best traffic person. And almost cried

Oh, my God, if you guys were in an accident -- why would you crash? And I mean it Because I care about the Austin citizens. And y'all need to care about yourselves, too, please. So, please, make sure you're staying safe on the roads.
Don't make me cough on this microphone.
I will.
I'm going to - we going to have to work on Tex-Dot. Working with us.
Oh, period.
Just sitting there, saying "we got it"
Yeah, we got the new traffic coverage for you.
Yeah.
Yeah, we're going to syndicate this traffic.
With care.
With care, right.
Traffic with care.
Traffic with care and love. We want y'all to feel it.
Yeah, sponsored by. We're going to get that in there, too.
Sponsored by love.
Yes.
And shea butter. Love and shea butter. It's all you need in this world.

Oh, my God. Because, you know, shea butter can also act as a skin protector. Also, to help, you know, because us colored people need protection from the sun also. Don't think that we don't get, you know. I know I just woke some folks up.
Hey, yeah.
"Did she just say colored? Did she call us colored?"
Hey, but you black.
"Hey, mama, what's colored? What does that mean?" "I don't know! What color are they?"
It means you color color in your skin.
You're not yourself.
It means you're definitely not…
You're not yourself.
Because in reality, like my grandmother, she was not a black woman.
Heard. Okay.
She was a colored woman.
Ooooooooooh.
And that's what she would tell you. "Your shoes. Those shoes are black. We're not that color."
Oh.
And so, you know.
Okay. I guess. But I mean -
Here's my rebellio- here's my rebellious cousin: "Come on, Gran. It's about the culture."
Right.
"It's about - " You know what I'm saying?
No, jeez-
"It's about the culture. The black culture." And she was like, "Yeah. Whatever. Black ain't all that beautiful. We different colors. We come in different colors." And so, it was that generation.
But yeah, I guess it is. It's a generational thing.
Because here's the key. If, you know, she probably at this time, she would have been in her 90s. So, if a 90-year-old white woman said, "colored girl, y'all be acting kind of funny."
Oh, I'd be acting UP.
And I would laugh. I would laugh. I would laugh.
I'm about to beat up that old lady.

I've done customer service and heard a [laughs] and the elderly white woman said, "well, they're nice people that live next to me, but they don't get the trash can up when they spill. You know, they're nice colored people." I laugh so hard. Because I almost said, "ma'am, what color are they?"
I don't know, I used to think, I used to think white folks was colored. Because I was like, man, they change so many different colors in the course of a day.
They do. They do. They be pink.
Pink, pink, red. Yeah. So, you know.
They got all the hues. We call them sunset.
They got a lot of different colors.
I love my tan in the summertime, though. I have to change my makeup because I darken.
I feel you. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
By the time the winter comes -
You got your winter color. You got your sun - yeah, your summer.
And it's so funny when they realize that we tan, too.
Oh, my God.

Yeah, because I came back from a weekend. And I had, like, just a shirt that kind of just, like, the cold shoulder. So, you can look at my arm and see my tan line. And they were like, "oh, my God. Do you have a tan?"
it's like, "yeah, girl."
What, you think we done?
That's what I'm saying.
Pop us back in that oven. We not finished cooking yet.
We can get darker.
We can get darker. Come on.

No, please. I want to. I want to get darker, for real. Also, one of us, somebody called in recently to say that they wanted to put some, show some love to some Austin acts when we were talking about black artists, if Austin ever had, like, a festival. They said they wanted to shout out Ruthie Foster. [Come on, now.] Malphore Milligan. [Yes.] Gary Clark Jr. [Yes, definitely.] Say, like, some of our Austin black legends, you know, show some love to them. So, you know, I wanted to say that on the air. Hopefully, you know, they're feeling recognized and seen with what I had to say.

Oh, you know? I kind of thought about that the new, well, it's not really a new festival, but the festival that's really popping. I really want to go with Flog Gnaw. Camp Flog Gnaw. In Dodger Stadium? They got, I mean, almost everybody that y'all named pulled up to the show. So, yeah, if Camp Flog Gnaw every year, I feel like right now, that's probably the biggest festival, even bigger than Coachella.
Oh, yeah.
I think Flog Gnaw is the spot, you know.
It really is.
Yeah, they actually televised it last year on Hulu.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, you got to watch all the days on Hulu and all the different stages. So, yeah, I'm, you know, shout out to Tyler. He has really created a franchise with that Camp Flog Gnaw.
Yeah, so we're supposed to be having some people pull up, right?
And so, yeah, we'll get into that.
Okay.

No pressure. [Laughs] Okay, pressure. No pressure. But thank you, Linda. She's another artist that you'll be able to see some of the children that they work with in their generational XYZ art camps that they have. You'll be able to see some of those young artists in the Pecan Street Festival this year. Don't forget, it's changed. It'll be out there by Beecaves and by the gallery. And it's always-
Where does that start?
A free festival - tomorrow.
Oh.
Saturday and Sunday. And of course, they're going to have like a petting zoo and some rides for the kids.
I do like a petting zoo.
Yes, but you know, it's always featuring, it's always going to have some food out there somewhere.
Well, it's black people. There better be some food. I'm sorry. If black people go to an event and they ain't got no grub, what is going on?
It's going to be a very short event.
That's what I'm saying. People leaving.
It's going to be brief. It's going to be brief.

Music. Now, this is a festival that used to go on and just had a little, you know, a little, not really a controversy, but people had their opinions because this was something that used to, you know, go on right downtown. On 6th Street. So it was kind of easy to get to when, you know, you get your rail. If you live way out of the suburbs, you get the rail. Or take the bus, you know. And so now, you do have to drive out there because I didn't check. And so if they're going to have some shuttle buses, I'm going to need the coordinators of the Pecan Street Festival to give me a call at 512-836-9554. If you are connecting to the festival, give us a call. If you connected with the festival to let us know if they're going to be shuttle buses that may be, like, taking us from a certain plane, like maybe, like, Barton Creek Mall. Yeah, because we want to know. Or someone over there by Zilker. That's going to take the ones that don't want to drive all the way out there. Or maybe just want to take their kids. You know what I'm saying? Because it was convenient for everybody to get to. And so now you have to have a car in order to get.
